Issues.Title: fix: DataBindings.Remove/Clear unsubscribe from the INotifyPropertyChanged.PropertyChanged event
Issues.Body:
A regression introduced in #854 that caused bindings in the middle object to remain after those were unwired in the target control.

Fixes #1679

<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

- Add tests

Issues.Title: Should we try to shrink the size of our assemblies?
Issues.Body:
Some important driving questions:
1. what kinds of customers want us to shrink our assemblies?
2. why do they want smaller assemblies? 
3. do customers care about small reductions in size or do they want larger reductions?

Some top-level options:
1. run a tool which removes "dead" code. This may be difficult considering
    * some code may only be exercised by the designer and thus may appear dead
    * the linker may not understand all the ways code and non-code jell together
2. run a tool at linking-time to removed types from the assemblies which are not used (same issues as with 1)
3. make more assemblies
    * this would involve making the system.windows.forms assembly a facade and finding smart / clever types to move to other assemblies, such as system.windows.forms.datagridview
    * this would make it so that if apps only need certain types, they can use more specific project references, reducing the size of their application at runtime
4. comment out unused types (same issues as 1 and 2 while also being manual and prone to developer-error)

Any additional thoughts?
Any customer out there particularly invested in / desirous of this?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Should we try to shrink the size of our assemblies?" (#1890)

Issues.Title: Update checks for screen.WorkingArea
Issues.Body:
## Proposed changes

Update checks for `Screen.WorkingArea` to allow for multiple monitors of different resolutions.

For instance, with two monitors where the right monitor is vertical, `Bounds: {X = 2560 Y = 0 Width = 1440 Height = 2560}`.

## Customer Impact

Test change only.

## Risk

Low.

Issues.Title: Review COM interface declarations for conflicting ComImport/ComVisible attributes
Issues.Body:
During review of PR #1868 I noticed `IOleInPlaceActiveObject` was declared with both `[ComImport]` and `[ComVisible(true)]`. This is wrong, ComVisible(true) is for interfaces owned by the assembly, ComImport is for external interfaces.

In desktop framework this probably has little consequence since the assemblies come preinstalled, but now that its possible to deploy WinForms with an application it may more likely be processed by tools like regasm or TLB generators, which attempt to register COM interop owned by the assembly.

When ComVisible(true) is present this will cause registry corruption by overwriting the true owners registry entries (usually owned by Windows OS) and replacing them by .NET based values. For interfaces I believe this mostly replaces the ProxyStubClsid32 pointing to another implementation than the original entries used to have.

There should be a review for conflicting ComImport/ComVisible(true) entries, or better, just review ComVisible(true) in general and make sure it is only placed on classes/interfaces owned by WinForms.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Review COM interface declarations for conflicting ComImport/ComVisible attributes" (#1878)
